direction.raw_text: : EXT.  BACKYARD - LUNCHTIME Graham holds his hand over the barbecue to see if it's at the right temperature.  The other hand holds a cordless phone to his ear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (into phone) ... Lee actually the reason I'm calling is about Lionel. Graham stokes the coals with a LONG BARBECUE FORK.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (into phone) Was he at home last night with you or was he out and about with the Wolfington brothers? Graham moves around from behind the barbecue and heads towards the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (into phone) Well, there was a little mischief done to our crops last night. Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (into phone) I know he's a fine boy... No one's saying otherwise. Graham steps through the back screen door into his KITCHEN. Graham holds the phone a little closer and talks in a HUSHED VOICE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (into phone) Listen Lee, I don't even mind if it was him.  You could just talk to him and that would be enough for me... See it was kind of strange finding the crops like that.  The kids were... confused by it.  It would take the strangeness away if we knew it was Lionel and the Wolfington brothers just messing around... (beat, listens) The movies... (beat) Are you sure? (beat) Okay, then... Thank you for your patience Lee. Graham turns off the phone.  He turns to put it on the counter and realizes his children are seated on the kitchen floor with one of their two German Shepherds.  There is a LARGE PUDDLE on the kitchen tiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Houdini peed.  I think he's sick. Graham looks at the majestic dog.  It's shivering.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take him outside.  I'll call Dr. Reynolds. Morgan and Bo lead their dog out with worried expressions on their faces. Graham grabs a handful of paper towels and places it on the puddle of urine.  The DOORBELL rings with Graham still on his knees on the kitchen floor.  He leans back so he can see down the hall. A balding police officer stands on the other side of the screen door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was quick Edgar.  I only called you boys about two hours ago. OFFICER EDGAR PASKI nods that he knows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Kindleman twisted her ankle as she put it, "diving for her life" when a bunch of school kids rode down the sidewalk on skateboards. She went down to Thorton's store this morning and started spitting on the new skateboards.  Spitting! By the time I got there, Mrs. Kindleman had sprayed the whole damn place... She must have had a cold or something.  It was enough to turn a grown man's stomach. Beat.  Graham stares at Officer Paski.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So what happened to your crops?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think it's contaminated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't even know what that word means. He drinks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not contaminated.  It's just tap water.  Pour it in his bowl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It tastes funny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He licks his butt everyday.  He's not going to mind. Bo shrugs and pours it into the bowl.  Beat. Houdini just sits staring at them.  He is not shivering.  He doesn't drink.  He is unnaturally still. Bo pushes the bowl closer. HOUDINI MOVES... BO'S HAND PULLS BACK... HOUDINI'S JAWS SNAP SHUT IN THE AIR WHERE HER HAND USED TO BE.  HE WAS JUST A FRACTION OF A SECOND LATER... BEAT.  The children turn white.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Houdini? HOUDINI BEGINS TO GROWL.  Bo stands up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bo don't run. Houdini crouches down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's wrong boy? THE DOG'S GROWL BECOMES DEEP, MENACING.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stop it Houdini! The German Shepherd trembles.  His body tightens.  He's about to leap.  Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (soft) Bo, run.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (yelling) It's the strangest thing Father.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (yelling) Don't call me Father.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (yelling) What's that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (yelling) Don't call me Father.  It's just Graham now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (yelling) Sorry. They stands in awkward silence fifty feet away from each other.  Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (yelling) You said something was strange. What's strange?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (yelling) The footprints.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (yelling) What about them?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (yelling) There are none.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (soft) Look at where it's bent over. Graham stands next to him and leans in.  The joint where the stalk bends from the ground is a perfect "L".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not broken.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What kind of machine can bend a stalk of corn over without cracking it? Graham looks around at the hundreds of thousands of corn stalks bent over each other in a perfect wave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (softy) Can't be by hand... It's too perfect. Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doesn't sound much like Lionel Prichard and the Wolfington brothers.  They can't take a piss without wetting the front of their pants. Graham, nods in agreement.  Officer Paski stands up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Second thing this week I can't explain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What was the first thing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some animals around the county exhibiting uncharacteristic behavior.  Sometimes violent behavior.  Theo Henry had two of his fingers bit off by his cow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sounds like a virus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No Father, they're edgy.  On alert. Like they act when they smell a predator around... Peeing on themselves and everything. We see a thought catch in Graham's eyes.  He turns back and stares in the direction of the house.  You can barely see the roof over the crops.  Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (preoccupied) Edgar, please don't call me Father. The two men stand as the wind blows lightly around them. Officer Paski notices the still expression on Graham's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's wrong? Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't hear my children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (soft) He wanted to kill Bo. Beat.  Graham stares at his ten-year old son.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did he hurt you? Beat.  Morgan nods, "No."  His tough exterior breaks as his face starts to tremble.  He starts crying.  Graham picks him up in his arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispers in his ear) I'm so sorry Morgan. Graham reaches up for Bo.  She has dirt and tears on her face.  Beat.  She slowly climbs down.  Graham carries both his children as they cry in his arms. He starts towards the house.  Merrill walks out from the back holding a bowl of food.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I used a little Tabasco in the potato salad. Merrill sees Houdini lying under the jungle gym.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Houdini's sick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please tie up Isabelle to the back of the shed.  Make sure the knot's tight. Merrill stands still with potato salad in his hands.  He nods. The children watch over their father's shoulder as Merrill runs to their other German Shepherd sitting quietly near the house and leads her by her collar across the yard to the shed. Graham reaches the porch of his house and opens the screen door. The last thing the children see as they enter the house, is the image of Officer Paski pulling the barbecue fork out of their dead dog's neck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're tough cookies, those two. They think Houdini's playing with you up there. (beat) At least it got them to sleep. Graham stares off.  Beat.  He smiles a little.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay Miss Puzzle Master.  I got one for you... What can make geometric shapes the size of a football field... and what would scare every animal in this county? (beat) Have you figured it out yet? (smiles) You probably have... (beat) Give me a hint Colleen... Is it bigger than a bread box?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the matter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I saw a monster.  Can I have a glass of water? Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's wrong with the water next to your bed?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It tastes old. Graham slowly gets up from the bed.  He takes his daughter's hand and starts out of the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the rule about getting up in the middle of the night?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only for pee or poop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right. Graham leads his four-year old daughter down the darkened hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (soft) What are you thinking about?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (soft) Why do you talk to mom when you're by yourself? Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (soft) It makes me feel better.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (soft) Does she ever answer back?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (soft) No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (soft) She doesn't answer me either. Beat.  They both sit quietly for a moment. Graham's eyes drift to the bedroom window.  A LARGE SILHOUETTED FIGURE STANDS ON THE ROOF IN THE DARKNESS AND STARES AT HIM. THE FIGURE MOVES.  HIS SHADOW PASSES OVER THE CHILDREN'S BEDROOM AS HE JUMPS FROM THE ROOF. Graham stands.  He looks to his daughter with startled eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (soft) Get under a blanket.  They can't get you under the blankets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, this guy is trying to scare us.  He's messed with our property, he's coming around the house.  It's time for an ass whoopin'!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is not an intelligent way to approach this. Merrill opens the front door.  It's pitch black outside. Merrill turn to Graham and gestures with his fingers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispering) We both go outside and move around the house in opposite directions. We act crazy, insane with anger. Make him crap in his pants and force him around till we meet up on the other side. Merrill brings his fingers together at the end of a circle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispering) Explain, act crazy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispering) Curse and stuff.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispering) I'm not going to curse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispering) You don't mean it.  It's just for show.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispering) It doesn't sound natural when I curse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispering) Just make noises then.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispering) Explain noises.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispering) Are you going to do this or what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispering) No I'm not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispering) You want him coming in the house next time? Beat. They HEAR MOVEMENT OUTSIDE.  Merrill and Graham look out into the darkness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (hushed tone) On the count of three. (beat) One... two... three. Merrill and Graham go out the front door in opposite directions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're gonna beat your ass bitch!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ahhhh... I'm insane with anger. Graham spots a LARGE FIGURE darting around the corner ahead of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've lost my mind!  It's time for an ass whoopin'!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm gonna tear your head off! Merrill charges.  WE JUST MAKE OUT MOVEMENT IN THE DARKNESS AS THE FIGURE DISAPPEARS AROUND THE CORNER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I cursed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I heard. Graham's eyes drift above them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's on the roof. They follow the roof around the corner.  They find themselves in the backyard. Their eyes catch movement away from the house.  They just catch A GLIMPSE OF THE LARGE FIGURE as he disappears into the crops.  The swing on the swing set is still moving from being hit. They stare across the yard silently.  ALL WE HEAR IS THEIR HEAVY BREATHING.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was very dark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes it was.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't describe him at all? Don't you think that's find of odd?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It does seem kind of odd doesn't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know whether to look for a midget or a -- GRAHAM He definitely wasn't a midget.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. (beat) So he was tall?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Merrill) I would say so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Probably.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Over six feet? Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was very dark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, it was.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've established that. (beat) Just tell me about his clothing then. Graham and Merrill stare at Edgar Paski.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Was he wearing a Scottish kilt or jeans? They keep staring.  Edgar closes his pad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me ask you two something. Don't be embarrassed by the answer. It is possible... Just possible now, you might have been chasing each other around?  You said you went in opposite directions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edgar, it sounds as strange to me saying it, as it is to you hearing it.  But we couldn't see him.  He stayed mostly in the shadows.  All we could make out was movement. (beat) But I'll tell you something with absolute certainty.  There was someone watching our house last night.  He was looking in my children's windows and I want you to find him Edgar. (beat) I need you to take this seriously, just incase, it is something serious. The three men stand in the doorway.  Edgar opens his pad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I apologize. Morgan walks up to the front door.  He holds up a baby monitor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I use Bo's old baby monitor as a walkie-talkie?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It needs batteries.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edgar, come inside. The three men follow Morgan into the house.  They pass through the family room where Bo stands at the television. She is staring at the screen.  ON THE SCREEN IS AERIAL FOOTAGE FROM A HELICOPTER.  THE FOOTAGE IS OF A LARGE FIELD WITH ENORMOUS CIRCLES AND DIAMONDS CARVED INTO ITS CROPS. Bo changes the channel.  She finds a cartoon.  She sits down on the sofa. Morgan and the men, can't see the screen, and move into the KITCHEN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How certain are you, that this was a male?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know any girls can run like that. Graham opens one of the cabinets and pulls down some batteries.  He hands them to Morgan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: These are D's; I need double A's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have some upstairs. Graham starts out of the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know Merrill.  I've seen some of those women on the Olympics.  They could out run me easy. They all move into the FAMILY ROOM. Bo watches cartoons.  THE CARTOON MUSIC AND CARTOON PRAT FALLS FILLS THE ROOM.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This guy got on the roof in like a second.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bo, can you turn down the volume until Officer Paski leaves? Bo nods and moves to the television.  The pack of men follow Graham up the STAIRS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That roof is over ten feet high.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's telling you the truth, Edgar. Whoever it was, is very strong and can jump pretty high. They arrive on the landing and follow Graham into his bedroom.  He moves into his BATHROOM. They all move in with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They got women's high jumping in the Olympics.  They got these Scandinavian women who could jump clean over me. Graham takes the clock radio from the sink.  Tries to open the back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shoot, it needs a screw driver.  I have double A's in here. Graham waves the radio.  The men and Morgan move out of the bathroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know you're making a point Edgar. I just don't know what it is. They moves down the STAIRS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yesterday afternoon, an out of town woman stopped by the diner and started yelling and cussing cause they didn't have her favorite cigarettes at the vending machine. Scared a couple of customers.  No one's seen her since... My point is, we don't know anything about the person you saw.  We should just keep all possibilities available. They move through the FAMILY ROOM. Bo's cartoon is replaced by a special report news icon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dad, where's the remote? Bo starts looking around the couch. Graham stops before entering the kitchen.  The group stops with him.  He looks at Bo searching the couch.  He walks over to the television. There are three glasses of water on the TV set.  He stands next to the set.  Doesn't see what's on the screen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bo, you're too old to still be doing this.  The rule is, you take a glass of water, you finish it. (beat) Now what's wrong with this one? Bo stops looking through the sofa cushions and looks to her father.  Looks at the glass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's dust in it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This one?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A hair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This one?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Morgan took a sip.  It has his amoebas in it. Beat.  Bo turns back to her search.  Graham tucks the clock radio under his arm and collects the three glasses.  He heads towards the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excluding the possibility that a female Scandinavian Olympian was running around outside our house last night, what else is a possibility?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not done asking questions and I don't appreciate the sarcasm. They follow Graham and Morgan through the swinging door into the KITCHEN. Graham puts the glasses in the sink with a group of other half-filled water glasses and opens the drawer to pull out a screwdriver.  He starts opening the clock radio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you have anyone who might have a grudge or something against you? Maybe a church member, who might not have liked the fact, that you left the church? Graham looks at Edgar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you owe anybody money?  You can tell me off the record if you need too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Morgan hands Graham the baby monitor and Graham starts replacing the batteries.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is anything missing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Graham hands Morgan the monitor.  He turns it ON.  THERE IS A STATIC CRACKLE WITH SPIKES OF SOUND.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's still making the noises.  It's broken.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's old Morgan. Morgan heads out of the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen, I was out of line with that whole female Scandinavian Olympian thing. Edgar nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's just that, I'm pretty strong and pretty fast.  And I was running as fast as I could.  And this guy... (embarrassed smile) He was just toying with us. Beat.  Merrill walks out of the kitchen.  Graham watches Edgar think it over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Could everyone just take a seat on the couch.  I have some preliminary thoughts. Morgan sits with his monitor next to Bo, who quietly watches the TV.  Merrill and Graham squeeze in next to Morgan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There are three possibilities here. We'll call them one, two and three. The level one scenario is that there is a sane individual, who for real reasons wants to do you harm. I really don't believe that's what we're looking at here.  In my opinion, whoever this is, they don't want to do harm to you all. That's kind of clear. (beat) The level two scenario is, this is a mentally unstable person who's fixated on you and your family. This is a possibility, but a very slim one. (beat) I assure you I will treat all three possibilities carefully, but in all likely hood we are looking at what we'll call a level three scenario. He's a watcher.  Someone who this is a game for.  He's laying low. Doesn't want to be seen.  But he wants to watch you.  Study you folks. Officer Paski walks towards the windows.  Graham, Merrill and Morgan follow him with their eyes.  Officer Paski walks next to the television. ON THE SCREEN WITH THE SOUND ALMOST MUTED, IS AN AERIAL SHOT FROM A HELICOPTER.  A DIFFERENT ONE THAN BEFORE.  THE FOOTAGE IS OF A VAST FIELD OF CROPS.  THERE ARE TWO DIAMONDS FLANKING TWO SIDE OF A TRIANGLE IN THE CENTER OF THE FIELD. Officer Paski turns to them. Graham, Merrill and Morgan stare at the screen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now I don't want you all to worry about this no more.  You're making more of this than it is. (beat) You guys have had a tough couple of days with the vandalism to the crops and the death of your shepherd. (beat) Maybe you guys should do something fun?  Let me worry about this person.  Let me find out who it is and then -- What the hell are you people looking at? Edgar comes around to see the screen. WE ARE ON A TV SCREEN.  THE CROPS SWAY IN THE BREEZE. A HANDFUL OF PEOPLE ARE WAVING FROM THE DIAMONDS ON THE FIELD.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll be damned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Turn up the volume Bo. Bo gets up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't find the remote. She presses the up arrows on the TV controls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: images were shot yesterday afternoon by a thirty-four year old local camera man in Kerala, a southern city of India.  It is the eighteenth reported crop circle found in that country in the last seventy-two hours. The television report cuts to Columbia University PROFESSOR.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crop circles first emerged in the late seventies with the renewed interest in extraterrestrial life. They died out by the early eighties; dismissed as hoaxes. This new resurgence is wholly different.  Elements of it are unexplainable.  The speed and the quantity in which it has appeared implies the coordination of hundreds of individuals over many countries... (beat) There is only a limited amount of explanations.  Either this is one of the most elaborate hoaxes ever created, or basically... (beat) It's for real. Morgan takes the asthma inhaler from his pocket and breathes in deeply.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (wonder) Extraterrestrials.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What in God's name is going on? Beat. THE ROOM GOES SILENT as everyone watches the images on the television screen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't ask me what I think.  Cause I can't think straight right now. I'm going back to the station. Have a cup of Marcia's coffee and try to think clear.  After that I might make some calls. (beat) Hoaxes... People got way too much time on their hands. Edgar turns back to Graham.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I'll tell you something, what I said in their, still goes.  You and your family have been through a lot in the last two days... Not to mention what happened to you all seven months ago.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Six months. Edgar stares at Graham.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And three weeks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's left its mark still.  The last thing these children need to do, is worry about some crazy things happening in the world.  Take them into town.  Get their minds -- your mind, on everyday things.  It's good medicine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's good advice... (beat) Say hi to Marcia for me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You take care of yourself... (beat) Graham.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... signs intended to be seen from the sky -- CLICK.  Graham TURNS IT OFF.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No radio either... Just for a while. Morgan nods and then plops back into the backseat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Book money. Morgan holds out his hand.  Graham gives his son a look as he reaches into his back pocket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only one. Morgan takes the money Graham gives him, then takes Bo's hand and walks down the sidewalk. Graham watches them turn into a store. Merrill steps onto the sidewalk.  Hands in his pockets as he walks away. Graham turns and calls after him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (calls out) Meet back in fifteen minutes. Merrill waves over his shoulder.  He keeps walking. Graham starts across the street to the pharmacy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Extraterrestrials?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what they keep alluding to. It's just a bunch of crock. They're trying to sell sodas, plain and simple.  I've been watching these reports since morning.  I've seen twelve soda commercials so far.  Twelve!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you have book on extraterrestrials?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't tell me you believe this horse manure? Morgan shrugs.  Mrs. Nathan pushes her husband aside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As a matter of fact, I think we have one.  Came by mistake in a shipment.  Decided to keep it for city people. Mrs. Nathan points over to the far corner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Last row.  Third book from the left honey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why is no one saying the obvious? This is just a rash case of copycats.  Someone, somewhere, does the first one.  It's on TV, it's on the internet.  In less than an hour a couple hundred people get the same brilliant idea and here we are... on the verge of mass hysteria.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was asthma medicine right Father?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For Morgan Hess.  And it's not Father anymore. The Pharmacist looks back at Graham and then reaches up and TURNS OFF THE RADIO.  She quietly finds the prescription on the shelf and moves to the counter across from Graham. She doesn't ring it up.  She just stands there fiddling with the bag holding Morgan's medicine.  Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I ask you a favor Father? Graham stares at the girl.  Beat.  He nods "yes."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I take confession with you? Beat.  Graham leans forward on the counter and takes the girl's hands in his.  He talks very slowly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tracey, I -- am -- not -- a -- reverend -- anymore.  I haven't been for six months.  You know this. Beat.  When Tracey speaks her VOICE IS A BIT SHAKY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All this stuff on TV... (beat) Joe Gills was in here talking about the end of the world... I'm just a little scared. (beat) Please.  I need to take confession with you. Graham looks at the young girl's teary eyes.  He exhales slowly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got it figured. Merrill realizes the crewcut guy is talking to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've had two separate folks tell me they think there are strangers around these parts the last couple of nights.  Can't tell what they look like, cause they're staying in the shadows -- covert like.  No one's got hurt mind you... And that's the give away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (doesn't see) I see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's called probing.  It's a military procedure.  You send a reconnaissance group, very small, to check out things.  Not to engage, but to evaluate the situation.  Evaluate the level of danger.  Make sure things are all clear...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clear for what? The crewcut guy savors the beat of silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... For the rest of them. It takes a second, but Merrill smiles.  The crewcut guy smiles back.  Merrill points at a poster.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have a pamphlet or something I can read? The crewcut guy reaches to a stack of brochures.  Picks the top brochure and hands it to Merrill. The crewcut guy begins to stare at Merrill closely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey you didn't used to play baseball did you? Merrill looks up from the brochure.  Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shit.  I know you.  You're Merrill Hess.  I was there that day you hit that five hundred and eighty seven footer over the left field wall and set the record.  That thing had a motor on it... It's still the record right? Merrill not, "yes."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (soft) I got the bat at home... On the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You got two minor league home run records don't you? Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Five.  The five longest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Boy, why aren't you in the pros making stacks of cash and getting handfuls of T and A?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cause he also has the minor league strike out record. Merrill turns to the young man, about his age, who sits at the folding table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello Lionel. LIONEL smirks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He'd just swing as hard as he could every time.  It didn't matter what the coach said, didn't matter who was on base, he'd whip that bat through the air as hard as he could... Looked like a lumber jack chopping down a tree. (beat) Merrill here, struck out more times than any two players. Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You really hold the strike out record? Beat.  Merrill tucks the pamphlet in his jacket.  Looks like he's not going to say anything.  When he does, the words are soft and worn; they've been said a hundred times.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Felt wrong not to swing. Beat.  The crewcut guy shakes his head.  Merrill turns and starts walking. As he passes Lionel, Merrill makes a small, quick move in Lionel's direction, like he might hit him.  Lionel flinches and covers his face. Merrill walks out the door of the army recruiting office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I cursed thirty-seven times last week... I said the f-word a couple times, but mostly "shits" and "bastards." (beat) Is "Douche bag" a curse? Graham glances at the girl as she sits sideways to him at the counter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I suppose it's in its usage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How about "John you're a douche bag for kissing Barbara?"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's a curse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then it's not thirty-seven.  It's seventy-one. Graham's eyes widen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I stole a bottle of Ruby red lip stick from K-mart... I punched my brother in the back three times... Graham looks around the empty store for help.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's contaminated. MRS. NATHAN YELLS TO MR. NATHAN AT THE FRONT OF THE STORE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carl, there's something wrong with our water! Morgan doesn't look up from the extraterrestrial book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your water is fine.  Bo has a thing about her drinking water.  She's had it her whole life.  Like a tick people have.  Except it's not a tick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (fascinated) Is that right? Bo shrugs.  She places the glass she sipped on the table with the other glass. Mrs. Nathan stares at the four-year old.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thirteen! Everyone turns to the front of the store where Mr. Nathan points to the TV screen.  A Coke Cola commercial is on. Beat.  Mrs. Nathan turns back to find Morgan holding out the extraterrestrial book to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll take it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pharmacy crowded?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't want any one of you spending time with Tracey Abernathy alone.  Is that understood? Beat.  Everyone nods, "yes." Graham puts the key in the ignition and turns the car on. Merrill watches as Graham's hand goes to put the car in reverse -- and then stops. Graham is staring out the windshield.  Merrill follows his stare to a thin, thirty-year old man in a LEATHER JACKET coming out of a store.  Merrill's face changes expression too.  They both stare as the man passes in front of the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (soft) Is that him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (soft) Yeah. Everyone in the car watches the man in the leather jacket as he steps off the sidewalk towards the truck.  It's here that he notices the stares.  He glances up to see the faces watching him from the station wagon. The leather jacketed man keeps moving to his truck.  He gets in, turns it on, and without looking over to the station wagon, backs out of the parking lot. Beat.  The Hess family sits quietly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who is he? Nobody says anything for the longest time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's the man who killed mom. Graham puts the station wagon in reverse and backs out into the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What if Bo's baby monitor is picking up signals from the extraterrestrials? Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All this crop stuff.  They did it twenty-five years ago.  It was a joke. THE MONITOR SPIKES WITH A SUDDEN CRACKLE.  MORGAN PULLS IT AWAY FROM HIS EAR.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's just static Morgan.  Turn it up and see. Morgan turns a knob on the side. THE VOLUME SUDDENLY JUMPS UP ON THE MONITOR.  WE HEAR BEEPS IN THE STATIC.  THE RED LIGHTS ON THE FRONT OF THE BABY MONITOR LIGHT UP WITH EACH BEEP.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a code.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me see that please. Morgan hands Graham the monitor in the front seat.  THE BEEPS COME AND GO AS THEY GET COVERED BY THE STATIC.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's noise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's broken Morgan.  It'll just keep doing this. (beat) Let's get out of the car okay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We might lose the signal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We can't just sit in the car in our own driveway like this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll look like mental patients. Beat.  Nobody gets out of the station wagon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm getting out now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't do it. Graham pulls the handle.  His door opens.  He waits before getting out.  The other three station wagon doors open right after. OUTSIDE CAR Graham stands and closes his driver side door. THE MONITOR CHANGES SOUNDS.  THE BEEPING DISAPPEARS.  THE STATIC BECOMES LOUDER, BECOMING A MOVING, SWIRLING SOUND TEXTURE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nobody move! Everyone becomes frozen, standing next to the station wagon. Three of the doors are open. IN THE TEXTURE OF SOUND, JUST FOR A MOMENT, WE HEAR SOMETHING THAT SOUNDS LIKE...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Voices.  Did you hear that? Everyone stares at the baby monitor in Graham's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not English though.  You heard the voices right Uncle Merrill?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I heard them Morgan. Graham doesn't move his arm.  He keeps it out in the air where he had it as he closed his door.  Graham looks to Merrill over the roof of the station wagon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's probably picking up another baby monitor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right. THE SWIRLING TEXTURE SOUND FLOATS THROUGH THE AIR ABOVE THE STATION WAGON.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me see it. Beat.  Graham moves.  He hands the monitor over the hood. Merrill reaches for it. THE SWIRLING, MOVING TEXTURE BECOMES LOUD AND FILLED WITH UNINTELLIGIBLE NOISES.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stop! Graham and Merrill freeze -- both touching the monitor over the roof of the station wagon. WE HEAR SOMETHING THAT SOUNDS LIKE A VOICE EMERGE AND THEN QUICKLY FADE AWAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It doesn't sound like words. Merrill concentrates on THE SWIRLING MOVING TEXTURE COMING FROM THE BABY MONITOR. Graham looks around at his rapt family.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See this is why we're not watching those news reports.  People get obsessed. (beat) I'm letting go now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No dad!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't do it!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll lose the signal! Graham looks at Merrill, who's now one of them.  Beat. Morgan is the first one to move.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't let go. He moves from the back passenger door to the back bumper where he begins to climb onto the station wagon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Morgan?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It gets clearer, the higher you hold it. Morgan crawls on the roof and takes the monitor ever-so gently out of Graham and Merrill's outstretched hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Morgan, be careful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got him. Merrill climbs up over the side and joins Morgan on the roof. Merrill keeps a hand on his nephew.  Morgan raises the monitor above his head. THE RED LIGHTS ON THE BABY MONITOR ALL TURN ON. THE SWIRLING TEXTURE COMING FROM THE MONITOR BECOMES SOMETHING MORE MECHANICAL, LIKE THE HUM OF LARGE EQUIPMENT IN THE DISTANCE. THE VOICE LIKE SOUNDS ARE UNDER A CRACKLE BUT ARE CLEARER AND LOUDER. Bo runs to the front bumper and climbs onto the hood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hold on. Graham cuts her off by taking a seat on the hood.  He takes hold of Bo.  All four are on the car now. Morgan stands up on the roof of the station wagon.  Merrill holds him by the waist. Bo tries to get up onto the roof by climbing over Graham and the windshield.  Graham boosts her up over his head with both hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merrill you got her. Merrill reaches out his free hand.  Bo reaches out to him. THE SOUND FROM THE MONITOR SUDDENLY CHANGES.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stop! Everyone STOPS exactly where they are.  Graham holds Bo over his head.  Bo reaches out to Merrill.  Merrill sits on the roof with one arm out.  Morgan stands with the baby monitor raised high in the air.  The Hess family remains very still on the hood of their station wagon as they listen. THE CRACKLING IS GONE.  THE VOICE-LIKE SOUNDS ARE CLEAR AND UPFRONT.  THERE ARE TWO DISTINCT TONES IN THE MIX.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (soft) There's two of them talking. THE VOICE-LIKE SOUNDS ARE NOT WORDS BUT MORE LIKE GRUNTS AND GURGLING LIKE SOMEONE DROWNING.  THE SOUNDS ARE BEING CREATED BY INHALES, NOT EXHALES.  A SEQUENCE OF THESE SOUNDS IN ONE TONE IS FOLLOWED BY SILENCE AND THEN THE SECOND TONE BEGINS ANOTHER SEQUENCE LIKE A CONVERSATION. Graham struggles to hold Bo up.  Bo struggles to keep her arms out.  Merrill struggles not to turn his face to the incredible SOUNDS ABOVE HIS HEAD. THE TONES ESCALATE IN VOLUME. Morgan's eyes widen as THE SEQUENCE OF SOUNDS BECOMES SHORTER AND FASTER.  THE TONES BECOME HARDER, ANGRIER.  THE SILENCES ALMOST GONE. THE VOICE-LIKE TONES REACH A LOUD FEVERISH PACE, ALMOST VIOLENT AND THEN WE HEAR A CLICK AND THEY'RE GONE. Beat.  Everyone looks up at the baby monitor.  The red lights are off.  ONLY THE BLAND HUM OF NORMAL STATIC COMES FROM IT'S SPEAKER. Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (soft) They hung up. Graham brings Bo down into his lap.  Morgan takes a seat next to Merrill on the roof.  The Hess family sits like mental patients on the top of their station wagon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know something?  Even entertaining the possibility of this for a minute has been exciting. Beat.  Graham starts to move.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can see how people can get carried away with this type of thing. Graham reaches the barbecue area.  There's a flashlight on the picnic table.  Graham TURNS THE FLASHLIGHT ON.  A NARROW BEAM FALLS ON THE GRASS FIVE FEET AHEAD OF HIM. Graham starts toward the crops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a kind of faith.  It's an intoxicating thing to believe in something you can't see. THE BEAM OF LIGHT FALLS ON THE WALL OF CORN CROPS LINING THE BACKYARD.  Graham steps right up to them.  He hesitates and then steps into the field of CORN CROPS. We can't see two feet in any direction.  Six foot stalks of corn line Graham on all sides.  THE FLASHLIGHT THROWS A WAVERING BEAM ON THE CROPS AHEAD OF HIM.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You were always good at that... THE BEAM OF HIS FLASHLIGHT FINDS A NARROW PATH.  Graham starts following it.  His shoulders brush crops on either side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Believing in things you couldn't see. (beat) You would have been the first person on that station wagon wouldn't you?  You and Morgan would have been wrestling for that baby monitor. SOMETHING MOVES UP AHEAD. Graham stops.  HE SHINES HIS LIGHT DOWN THE PATH.  Nothing but crops disappearing into darkness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It'll be secretly kind of sad for everybody, when this turns out to be -- all just make believe. THERE'S MOVEMENT RIGHT NEXT TO HIM.  Graham spins and aims the FLASHLIGHT AT THE CROPS TO HIS RIGHT.  THE LIGHT ONLY PENETRATES A FEW FEET INTO THE CROPS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (yelling) You're wasting your time here!  I'm not going to report this or anything you do to me crops, to the news or TV or anybody!  You're not going to get famous! Beat.  There is no response.  GRAHAM CAN HEAR HIS OWN BREATHING... IT SOUNDS HEAVY, ECHOISH... LIKE THERE'S TWO OF HIM. Beat.  Graham holds his breath.  THE SOUND OF SOMEONE ELSE BREATHING CONTINUES BEHIND HIM. Graham turns and drops the FLASHLIGHT at the same time.  THE BEAM OF LIGHT TURNS OFF WHEN THE FLASHLIGHT HITS THE GROUND. GRAHAM IS IN DARKNESS NOW.  HE LOOKS IN THE DIRECTION OF THE BREATHING.  BUT CAN'T SEE ANYTHING.  HIS OWN BREATHING IS FAST AND LOUD NOW. Graham kneels down and gropes in the darkness.  His hands search over the ground in all directions.  They finally touch the flashlight.  Graham quickly fumbles with it to find the "on" button.  He does. A BEAM OF LIGHT SHOOTS ACROSS THE GROUND.  SOMETHING POWDERY WHITE STANDS FIVE FEET AWAY. It instantly moves into the darkness.  Graham tries to get up.  He stumbles backwards into the crops.  He's tangled in crops as he struggles to rise.  He gets up and starts running. Leaves and stalks slap him from all directions.  He panics. He doesn't know where he is.  THERE IS SOMETHING COMING BEHIND HIM. Graham makes a sudden right turn.  He puts his hands in front of him to protect his face and eyes.  He's running as fast as he can.  HE HEARS STALKS OF CORN BREAKING BEHIND HIM. Another sudden turn, this time left.  Graham emerges into his BACKYARD. Graham keeps running across the yard.  ISABELLE BARKS FRANTICALLY. When Graham reaches the porch stairs, he stops and turns. There is no one behind him.  The wall of crops fifty feet away sway in the gentle night breeze. Graham gains control of his breathing.  He turns and walks to the screen door, slowing his breathing down with each step.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (soft) Okay. (beat) Let's turn on the TV.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: first appeared fifty two minutes ago. THE SCREEN FILLS WITH CRISP BLACKS.  WE ARE WATCHING VIDEO OF A NIGHT SKY OVER A DENSE CITY.  THE THOUSAND LIGHTS OF THE CITY FILL THE BOTTOM OF THE SHAKING IMAGE. ANOTHER SET OF LIGHTS DOT THE SKY ABOVE THE CITY.  THEY ARE ARRANGED IN TWO "V'S" SIDE BY SIDE. Bo puts her finger to the screen and counts the hovering lights.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fourteen. Morgan, Merrill and Graham stand silently before the television set.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mexico City officials as well as U.S. officials have confirmed that these are not air crafts from either government's airforce.  The first sighting was made by an Air Mexico 747 en route from Mazatlan to New York as the unidentified crafts entered Mexico City air space.  They were not detected by radar by either country. Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The crazies were right. Beat.  Everyone just watches the fourteen lights hovering on the screen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have to tape this... Morgan reaches into the pile of video tapes under the television stand.  He grabs one. Bo snatches the video as Morgan tries to put it into the VCR.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My ballet recital. Morgan stares at his sister.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gravely serious) Listen Bo.  This is very important. Everything people have written about in science books is going to change.  The history of the world's future is on the TV right now.  We need to record this so you can show your children this tape and say you were there... (beat) For your children Bo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My ballet recital.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dad! Graham doesn't take his eyes off the screen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (preoccupied) Find another tape. Graham and Merrill sit down at the same time on the sofa. They both have the same dazed, slow movements. Morgan rummages through the pile of videos frantically.  He finds one and reaches for the VCR.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uncle Merrill, I'm using your tape. Morgan slams the tape marked "Bay Watch" into the VCR and presses record.  He's breathing heavy now.  Wheezing actually. Morgan moves to the sofa and takes a seat in between his father and his uncle.  Bo walks over and squeezes in also. The four of them stare at the television.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... You're seeing a live feed from our NBC affiliate down in Mexico City.  The time there is 7:17pm. This image has not been adjusted or enhanced in any way.  What you're seeing is real. (beat) Everything they wrote in science books is about to change. Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (soft) Told you. Morgan brings his asthma spray to his mouth and inhales.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispers) Some people are probably thinking this is the end of the world. Graham turns his sleepy eyes away from the screen to Merrill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispers) That's true. Merrill looks his brother in the eyes.  Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispers) Do you think it's a possibility?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispers) Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispers) How can you say that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispers) That wasn't the answer you wanted?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispers) Can you at least pretend to be like you used to be?  Give me some comfort? Beat.  Graham thinks it over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispers) ... There are all different ways you can tell that there's someone really there watching out for us. You see signs.  Sometimes they're little ones.  You think of someone. The phone rings.  They're on the phone... Sometimes they're big, like fourteen lights hovering over Mexico City. (beat) Sure, there are a lot of people watching this who think this could be a bad thing.  But there are a lot of people watching this, who think it's a miracle.  A sign of God's existence.  It's all in how you look at things Merrill. (beat) What you have to decide is what kind of person you are?  Are you the type who believes in miracles and looks for signs or are you the kind who believes, things just happen by chance? Beat.  Merrill is deep in thought.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was at this party once.  I'm on a couch with Sara Mckinney.  She was just sitting there, looking beautiful and staring at me.  I go to lean in and kiss her and I realize I have gum in my mouth.  I turn and take out the gum.  Stuff it in my paper cup next to the sofa and turn around.  Sara Mckinney throws up all over herself. (beat) I knew the second it happened.  It was a miracle.  I could have been kissing her when she threw up. That would have scarred me for life.  I may never have recovered. Merrill looks at the TV screen.  Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm a miracle man.  Those lights are a miracle. Graham smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispers) There you go. Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispers) So which type are you? Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispers) Do you feel comforted?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispers) Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispers) What does it matter then? The two of them turn back to the silent screen of the television.  It's a long beat before Graham speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispers) Do you know what Colleen's last words were before they killed her? Beat.  Merrill turns and stares quietly at his brother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispers) She said, "See", and then her eyes glazed a bit and she said... "Tell Merrill to swing away." Merrill's mouth opens a bit.  Graham turns and chuckles at his expression.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispers) Do you know why she said that? Merrill nods, "No."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispers) Because the nerve endings in her brain were firing as she died, and some random memory of us at one of your baseball games popped into her head. (beat) There is no one watching out for us Merrill.  We're all on our own. Graham turns back to the television.  Beat. THE LIGHT OF THE TELEVISION FLICKERS ON THE FACES OF THE TWO BROTHERS AS THEY SIT WATCHING IN SILENCE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For the kids protection.  All they were doing was watching TV from five a.m.  I felt like they were getting obsessed like you said. They should be playing furry, furry rabbit or tea party or something right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's furry, furry rabbit?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (points) That's a game isn't it? (beat) Anyway... (points at the TV) There's been some interesting developments.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What time is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eleven a.m.  They're gone. Beat.  Graham looks at the TV screen.  There's a daylight shot of Mexico City.  The skies are empty above it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But they're not really gone.  We just can't see them.  Early this morning a bird flew right at the area where the lights were hovering last night. Merrill puts a finger in the sky on the screen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It stopped dead in the air and fell straight down. Merrill's finger trails to the bottom of the screen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They caught it on tape and they've been playing it all morning.  They found the bird.  His head crushed in.  When you see the footage it looks like the bird flew into a wall in the sky. (beat) They think they have some invisible shield thing going, like an optical illusion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bird could have had a heart attack and crushed his head when he fell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Already thought of.  Two other birds did the same thing an hour later.  Not as dramatic.  They lived.  But you could see they hit something. Graham looks at the empty sky on the screen with different eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're still there hovering.  In fact, some people think there's more of them now.  All over the place.  Over us even. (beat) And there's a theory about the crop circles now.  They think it could be some kind of landmark, visual mapping system -- so they can navigate.  Coordinate.  Makes sense doesn't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So the aliens can't read our minds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They tell you everything in this book. Morgan holds up the book he bought from Nathan's bookstore. Graham enters the room.  The children make space for him on the bed.  He takes a seat between them.  Morgan puts the book on his father's lap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It says they're probably very small
direction.name: direction

result.heading: THIRTY MILES OUTSIDE PHILADELPHIA" CUT TO

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  BACKYARD JUNGLE GYM - LUNCHTIME Bo walks from the house with a large glass of water.  She moves to Houdini, who sits in the shade by the picnic table. Morgan pokes the barbecue fork into two meat patties on the grill.  He places two pieces of cheese on the hamburgers, before walking over to Houdini. The two children sit down in the grass with the dog. Bo is about to pour the glass of water into the dog bowl. She stops.  Takes a tiny sip of the water first. She holds the glass out to Morgan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: JAWS SNAP SHUT IN THE AIR WHERE HER HAND USED TO BE

result.ToD: HE WAS JUST A FRACTION OF A SECOND LATER
result.heading: HE WAS JUST A FRACTION OF A SECOND LATER

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  CROPS - LUNCHTIME Officer Edgar Paski stands facing Graham fifty feet away. They are on opposite ends of the crop circle.  Beat. The crops all around them sway as the wind blows.  Beat. Officer Paski yells over the wind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  CORN CROPS - LUNCHTIME Officer Paski's knee touches the ground.  He points to a single stalk of corn laying flat on it's side.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: BARBECUE FORK DEEP IN ITS NECK

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  BACKYARD - LUNCHTIME Morgan watches the thin line of smoke rising from the charred patties on the grill next to the overturned picnic table. Morgan's attention moves as the crops part and his father and Officer Paski enter the backyard.  They stop cold when they look in his direction.  They begin a slow walk towards him. Morgan Hess is seated under the jungle gym with Houdini on his lap.  Morgan is petting Houdini's fur gently.  Bo is on top of the jungle gym curled up in a ball. As Graham and Officer Paski get closer, they see Morgan is crying. Then they see the dog is laying on it side and has a BARBECUE FORK DEEP IN ITS NECK. Beat. They stare at Morgan as he slowly pulls an inhaler from his pocket and brings it to his mouth.  He inhales the asthma spray.  Beat.  He lowers the inhaler so he can speak.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  BEDROOM - LATE EVENING Graham lies in bed.  He rests his cheek against the pillow as he lies by himself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: MILLION CRICKETS AND BUGS FILL THE NIGHT AIR WITH SOUND

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  HOUSE - NIGHT The large Hess farm house sits in the moonlight. A MILLION CRICKETS AND BUGS FILL THE NIGHT AIR WITH SOUND. THEY SUDDENLY STOP. AN UNNATURAL SILENCE FILLS THE YARD.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  BEDROOM - NIGHT Graham opens his eyes slowly as he stirs from his sleep.  His daughter Bo stares at him from the edge of the bed.  She is five inches away from his face. Graham gets startled.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  CHILDREN'S BEDROOM - NIGHT Morgan's body is half off his bed.  Graham gently lifts him back onto the pillow and covers him up. There are two glasses of water on Bo's bedside table.  Graham moves to Bo's bed.  He sits on the edge of it.  She stares back at him as she holds her panda.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: A LARGE SILHOUETTED FIGURE STANDS ON THE ROOF IN THE DARKNESS AND STARES AT HIM
HIS SHADOW PASSES OVER THE CHILDREN'S BEDROOM AS HE JUMPS FROM THE ROOF
NIGHT GREY SNOW FILLS THE SCREEN

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  FAMILY ROOM - NIGHT GREY SNOW FILLS THE SCREEN.  Merrill sleeps in front of the family room television. A hand gently shakes him.  Merrill wakes and looks up at his brother zipping up his overcoat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  FRONT DOOR - NIGHT Merrill quickly puts on his boots at the front door.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  MERRILL'S SIDE OF HOUSE - NIGHT Merrill is in a full sprint.  He hugs the side of the building as he runs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  GRAHAM'S SIDE OF HOUSE - NIGHT Graham runs through the darkness around the first corner of the house.  He waves his arms.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: THE LARGE FIGURE HAS COME TO A STOP IN THE SHADOWS AHEAD OF HIM
HE SEEMS TO BLEND INTO THE DARKNESS WHEN HE'S STILL

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  MERRILL'S SIDE OF HOUSE - NIGHT Merrill turns a corner full speed.  THE LARGE FIGURE HAS COME TO A STOP IN THE SHADOWS AHEAD OF HIM.  HE SEEMS TO BLEND INTO THE DARKNESS WHEN HE'S STILL.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: WE JUST MAKE OUT MOVEMENT IN THE DARKNESS AS THE FIGURE DISAPPEARS AROUND THE CORNER

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  SIDE OF HOUSE - NIGHT Graham and Merrill come screaming around two corners and come to a stop facing each other.  Beat. They look around, panting heavily.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: A GLIMPSE OF THE LARGE FIGURE
ALL WE HEAR IS THEIR HEAVY BREATHING

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  PORCH - DAY Officer Edgar Paski stands on the porch with his note pad open.  He faces Graham and Merrill.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: THE FOOTAGE IS OF A LARGE FIELD WITH ENORMOUS CIRCLES AND DIAMONDS CARVED INTO ITS CROPS
THE CARTOON MUSIC AND CARTOON PRAT FALLS FILLS THE ROOM
THERE IS A STATIC CRACKLE WITH SPIKES OF SOUND

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  FAMILY ROOM - DAY Graham moves to a windowsill where more glasses of water sit. He picks them up.  Sees two more on the coffee table.  He gives up and puts the two glasses back on the windowsill.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: THE FOOTAGE IS OF A VAST FIELD OF CROPS
THERE ARE TWO DIAMONDS FLANKING TWO SIDE OF A TRIANGLE IN THE CENTER OF THE FIELD
THE CROPS SWAY IN THE BREEZE
HANDFUL OF PEOPLE ARE WAVING FROM THE DIAMONDS ON THE FIELD

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  HESS DRIVEWAY - DAY The two men walk down the driveway to Edgar's patrol car.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: AFTERNOON WE MOVE THROUGH BACK ROADS OF BUCKS COUNTY
RURAL PENNSYLVANIA IN ITS MOST BEAUTIFUL

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  STATION WAGON - AFTERNOON WE MOVE THROUGH BACK ROADS OF BUCKS COUNTY.  RURAL PENNSYLVANIA IN ITS MOST BEAUTIFUL.  TREE LINED STREETS. WHITE PICKET FENCES.  APPLE ORCHARDS. The Hess family rides in their station wagon.  Graham drives. Merrill is shotgun.  The children are in the back. Morgan leans forward and TURNS ON THE RADIO.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  MAIN STREET - AFTERNOON Downtown Bucks County.  A group of small stores along a quiet street. The Hess station wagon pulls in front of a free parking meter. Graham steps out the driver's side and looks around.  Merrill puts change in the meter. Morgan walks up to Graham with Bo.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: PICTURE ON THE TELEVISION IS OF A WHEAT FIELD
THREE ENORMOUS TRIANGLES SURROUND A CIRCLE

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  NATHAN'S BOOKSTORE - AFTERNOON A mom and pop bookstore.  Three isles wide.  MR. AND MRS. NATHAN, a couple in their early seventies, sit behind their counter and watch a black and white TV.  The PICTURE ON THE TELEVISION IS OF A WHEAT FIELD.  THREE ENORMOUS TRIANGLES SURROUND A CIRCLE. Morgan steps up to the counter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . NATHAN
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . NATHAN
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . NATHAN
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . NATHAN
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  PHARMACY - AFTERNOON Graham waits at a white counter.  A gum chewing PHARMACIST in her early twenties, who looks like she's in her teens, glances through back shelves of medicines as she listens to the radio.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  ARMY RECRUITING OFFICE - AFTERNOON Merrill stares up at a poster with a muscular guy in an Army uniform standing at attention on a beach. We are in a narrow ARMY RECRUITING CENTER.  Inside the small storefront space is a desk.  A gentleman sporting a CREWCUT sits behind it. A young man, Merrill's age, sits at a side card table filling out some forms.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  PHARMACY - AFTERNOON PHARMACIST
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  NATHAN'S BOOKSTORE - AFTERNOON Bo sits at a tiny reading table and drinks a glass of water. There is another glass, half-full, on her table.  Mrs. Nathan watches as the little girl takes careful sips. Beat.  Bo looks up with a grimace.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: NATHAN AT THE FRONT OF THE STORE

dialogue.raw_text: . NATHAN
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . NATHAN
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . NATHAN (O.S.)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  STATION WAGON - AFTERNOON Merrill, Morgan and Bo are waiting in the parked car.  Beat. The driver's side opens and Graham sits in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: AFTERNOON THE SKY IS GOLDEN RED

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  HESS HOME - AFTERNOON THE SKY IS GOLDEN RED.  The crops sway hypnotically in a gentle breeze. The Hess station wagon pulls into their driveway.  It comes to a stop in front of the house.  The engine goes off.  No one gets out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: MUFFLED SPIKE OF NOISE IS HEARD FROM THE BACK SEAT

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  STATION WAGON - AFTERNOON All four sit quietly not getting out. A MUFFLED SPIKE OF NOISE IS HEARD FROM THE BACK SEAT. Graham and Merrill turn and see Morgan pull the baby monitor out of his jacket.  He holds it in his lap. Beat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: MONITOR SPIKES WITH A SUDDEN CRACKLE
MORGAN PULLS IT AWAY FROM HIS EAR
VOLUME SUDDENLY JUMPS UP ON THE MONITOR
WE HEAR BEEPS IN THE STATIC
THE RED LIGHTS ON THE FRONT OF THE BABY MONITOR LIGHT UP WITH EACH BEEP
THE BEEPS COME AND GO AS THEY GET COVERED BY THE STATIC
THE TEXTURE OF SOUND, JUST FOR A MOMENT, WE HEAR SOMETHING THAT SOUNDS LIKE
SWIRLING TEXTURE SOUND FLOATS THROUGH THE AIR ABOVE THE STATION WAGON
BECOMES LOUD AND FILLED WITH UNINTELLIGIBLE NOISES
HEAR SOMETHING THAT SOUNDS LIKE A VOICE EMERGE AND THEN QUICKLY FADE AWAY
RED LIGHTS ON THE BABY MONITOR ALL TURN ON
SWIRLING TEXTURE COMING FROM THE MONITOR BECOMES SOMETHING MORE MECHANICAL, LIKE THE HUM OF LARGE EQUIPMENT IN THE DISTANCE
VOICE LIKE SOUNDS ARE UNDER A CRACKLE BUT ARE CLEARER AND LOUDER
THE SOUND FROM THE MONITOR SUDDENLY CHANGES
THE VOICE-LIKE SOUNDS ARE CLEAR AND UPFRONT
THERE ARE TWO DISTINCT TONES IN THE MIX
VOICE-LIKE SOUNDS ARE NOT WORDS BUT MORE LIKE GRUNTS AND GURGLING LIKE SOMEONE DROWNING
THE SOUNDS ARE BEING CREATED BY INHALES, NOT EXHALES
A SEQUENCE OF THESE SOUNDS IN ONE TONE IS FOLLOWED BY SILENCE AND THEN THE SECOND TONE BEGINS ANOTHER SEQUENCE LIKE A CONVERSATION
THE SEQUENCE OF SOUNDS BECOMES SHORTER AND FASTER
VOICE-LIKE TONES REACH A LOUD FEVERISH PACE, ALMOST VIOLENT AND THEN WE HEAR A CLICK AND THEY'RE GONE
ONLY THE BLAND HUM OF NORMAL STATIC COMES FROM IT'S SPEAKER
EVENING WE ARE AT THE EDGE OF THE CROPS LOOKING BACK AT THE HOUSE
VIEW TURNS TO LOOK AT THE BARN THROUGH THE CROPS
WE TURN TO LOOK BACK AT THE HOUSE
THEN TURNS AND LOOKS DIRECTLY AT US FROM ACROSS THE YARD
PULL BACK INTO THE DARKNESS OF THE CROPS

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  BACKYARD - EVENING WE ARE AT THE EDGE OF THE CROPS LOOKING BACK AT THE HOUSE. The LIGHTS are on in the kitchen.  We see Graham, Merrill and the children doing dishes after dinner. The DOG IS BARKING FURIOUSLY. OUR VIEW TURNS TO LOOK AT THE BARN THROUGH THE CROPS. Isabelle, the remaining German Shepherd is tied to a post outside the barn.  The dog whips back and forth frantically. She keeps looking in our direction. WE HEAR A SCREEN DOOR OPEN.  WE TURN TO LOOK BACK AT THE HOUSE.  Graham steps out the back screen door with a bowl of dog food and a bowl of water. We watch him as he walks towards the frantic dog.  When he gets close, Graham slows.  He approaches the dog carefully. He places the two bowls close but not too close.  The dog has no interest in them.  She keeps barking and glaring in our direction. Graham watches her for a few moments, and THEN TURNS AND LOOKS DIRECTLY AT US FROM ACROSS THE YARD. WE PULL BACK INTO THE DARKNESS OF THE CROPS.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  BARN - EVENING Graham stands frozen looking across his yard.  Isabelle, the dog turns in desperate circles behind him.  Graham's eyes stay focused on the same point in the darkness.  He talks to no one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: A NARROW BEAM FALLS ON THE GRASS FIVE FEET AHEAD OF HIM
BEAM OF LIGHT FALLS ON THE WALL OF CORN CROPS LINING THE BACKYARD
THE FLASHLIGHT THROWS A WAVERING BEAM ON THE CROPS AHEAD OF HIM
BEAM OF HIS FLASHLIGHT FINDS A NARROW PATH
HE SHINES HIS LIGHT DOWN THE PATH
FLASHLIGHT AT THE CROPS TO HIS RIGHT
THE LIGHT ONLY PENETRATES A FEW FEET INTO THE CROPS
GRAHAM CAN HEAR HIS OWN BREATHING
THE SOUND OF SOMEONE ELSE BREATHING CONTINUES BEHIND HIM
THE BEAM OF LIGHT TURNS OFF WHEN THE FLASHLIGHT HITS THE GROUND
HE LOOKS IN THE DIRECTION OF THE BREATHING
HIS OWN BREATHING IS FAST AND LOUD NOW
BEAM OF LIGHT SHOOTS ACROSS THE GROUND
SOMETHING POWDERY WHITE STANDS FIVE FEET AWAY
THERE IS SOMETHING COMING BEHIND HIM
HE HEARS STALKS OF CORN BREAKING BEHIND HIM

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  KITCHEN - EVENING Graham steps into the kitchen.  His hair is messed.  His shirt has a few leaves from corn stalks stuck to it.  He locks the back door. The children don't notice his presence.  They're splashing each other at the sink as they clean the dinner dishes. Graham looks through the kitchen doorway to the family room. He sees Merrill there. Merrill's hands are in his pockets as he stares at the WOODEN BASEBALL BAT mounted above the fireplace.  Merrill doesn't notice him either. Graham takes two steps to the kitchen table and slowly takes a seat.  His breathing is a slow controlled pant.  He runs one shaky hand through his hair as he gathers himself and thinks.  His kind eyes stare down at the ground as he slows his mind.  Beat. Merrill is the first to notice him.  He moves from where the baseball bat is hung, into the kitchen.  As he passes the children at the sink, he turns off the faucet. The children stop playing and look up to Merrill.  They follow his stare to the kitchen table. Beat.  Graham looks up at them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: EVENING THE TV GOES ON WITH A CLICK
THE SCREEN BLOWS WHITE AND THEN IMMEDIATELY DARKNESS

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  FAMILY ROOM - EVENING THE TV GOES ON WITH A CLICK.  THE SCREEN BLOWS WHITE AND THEN IMMEDIATELY DARKNESS.  OUTLINES AND SHAPES EMERGE. THE SOUND POPS ON.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: WE ARE WATCHING VIDEO OF A NIGHT SKY OVER A DENSE CITY
THE THOUSAND LIGHTS OF THE CITY FILL THE BOTTOM OF THE SHAKING IMAGE
SET OF LIGHTS DOT THE SKY ABOVE THE CITY
THEY ARE ARRANGED IN TWO "V'S" SIDE BY SIDE

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  FAMILY ROOM - MIDNIGHT The family room lights are off now.  The TV is still on.  The SOUND IS MUTED.  There are a couple glasses of Bo's water on the television now. The fourteen lights are still hovering on the screen.  Morgan is asleep on Graham's lap.  Bo is asleep on Merrill's shoulder.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: LIGHT OF THE TELEVISION FLICKERS ON THE FACES OF THE TWO BROTHERS AS THEY SIT WATCHING IN SILENCE

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  FAMILY ROOM - DAY Graham's eyes open.  DAYLIGHT FILLS the family room.  He is alone on the couch.  Alone in the room. He looks to the television.  It's not there. Graham moves to his feet and look around the room.  His eyes stop on an EXTENSION CORD that runs from a wall outlet in the family room, across the front hall, and under a closet door. Graham moves to the door.  WE HEAR MUFFLED TELEVISION VOICES. Graham opens the CLOSET. Merrill looks up.  He's seated on a kitchen chair with the television on a roll-away stand crammed in with him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: LOOK OUT THE SAME WINDOW WE LOOKED OUT AT THE VERY BEGINNING
THE SOUND OF WHISPERING DRAWS HIS ATTENTION FROM THE WINDOW
HIS CHILDREN ARE WHISPERING IN THE NEXT ROOM

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  MASTER BEDROOM - DAY We are inside Graham's bedroom facing his bathroom door, which is closed.  The same sun-faded outline of where a large cross used to hang, is stained on the wall next to the door. Graham opens the bathroom door and steps out with wet hair. He towels it dry as he moves to his bedroom window. WE LOOK OUT THE SAME WINDOW WE LOOKED OUT AT THE VERY BEGINNING. The backyard is large and green with a wooden jungle gym.  A single tree throws shade onto a picnic table.  The back of the yard is lined by corn crops.  Golden and brown.  Six feet high. The crops go on well beyond our view.  Graham stares at them quietly.  Watching. Beat.  THE SOUND OF WHISPERING DRAWS HIS ATTENTION FROM THE WINDOW. He listens closely.  HIS CHILDREN ARE WHISPERING IN THE NEXT ROOM.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  CHILDREN'S BEDROOM - DAY Graham walks into the hall and looks in their room. Morgan and Bo are seated on the edge of their bed.  They have TIN FOIL wrapped around their heads like a helmet.  Graham stares at his children.
dialogue.name: dialogue
